payload.instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Frontend code lives in `apps/web/src`. Client routes use React Router under `src/routes`, reusable UI sits in `src/components`, and feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), utilities (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Vite dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle via Vite; run before deploys.
- `npm run preview`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules. Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach. Frontend env vars for Vite must be prefixed with `VITE_`.

<INSTRUCTIONS>
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
Frontend code lives in `apps/web/src`. Client routes use React Router under `src/routes`, reusable UI sits in `src/components`, and feature-specific logic is grouped inside `src/features/<feature>`. Shared hooks (`src/hooks`), utilities (`src/lib`), and design tokens (`src/styles`) keep cross-cutting concerns centralized. Static assets belong in `public`. Keep new modules aligned with this layout so imports remain predictable.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `npm run dev`: Launches the Vite dev server with React Fast Refresh.
- `npm run build`: Produces an optimized production bundle via Vite; run before deploys.
- `npm run preview`: Serves the latest build locally for smoke-testing production output.
- `npm run lint`: Executes the project-wide ESLint rules. Treat warnings as errors before opening a PR.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
Use modern ES modules with functional React components. Prefer two-space indentation and trailing commas, matching the existing files. Components that render UI should use PascalCase filenames (`ThemeToggle.jsx`), hooks use camelCase prefixed with `use` (`use-mobile.js`), and utility modules go in `src/lib` with hyphenated names. Favor Tailwind classes for styling; co-locate any component-specific CSS in `src/styles` only if a utility class will not suffice. Run `npm run lint` to ensure ESLint (configured in `eslint.config.mjs`) flags accessibility and performance regressions early.

## Testing Guidelines
Automated tests are not yet wired in. When adding them, group specs beside their feature (`src/features/navigation/__tests__/NavMenu.test.jsx`) so intent is obvious. Name files with `.test.jsx` or `.test.js`. For critical flows lacking automation, document manual verification steps in the PR description and exercise them against `npm run start` output. Keep database interactions mocked or pointed at disposable fixtures to avoid mutating shared environments.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
Craft commit subjects in the imperative mood (“Add navigation badges”), roughly 50 characters, with optional detail in the body. Combine related changes rather than batching multiple features. Pull requests should include: a concise summary, linked issue IDs, screenshots or clip recordings for UI changes, and notes on testing performed (`npm run lint`, manual checks, etc.). Request reviews from owners of affected areas (`src/features/<feature>` or shared libs) before merging.

## Environment & Configuration Tips
Local MySQL connectivity is managed via `src/lib/db.js`, which reads `DB_HOST`, `DB_PORT`, `DB_USER`, `DB_PASSWORD`, and `DB_NAME`. Place secrets in `.env.local`; never commit credentials. Tailwind configuration is defined through `components.json` and `postcss.config.mjs`. If you introduce new design tokens, update `src/styles/tokens.css` and keep class names consistent with Tailwind’s utility-first approach. Frontend env vars for Vite must be prefixed with `VITE_`.

</INSTRUCTIONS>

payload.text:
**Designing unified chart and controls**

This chunk breaks down how to merge two charts and their controls into a single chart with unified control elements. I'm thinking through the control options—like range selection, view mode (date or dimension), metric selection, and category filters—to create a clear, flexible UI that respects previous functionality but consolidates it neatly. A plan to redesign the component state and layout seems necessary to implement this moderate complexity task smoothly.

payload.text:
**Rebuilding UI layout and controls**

I'm planning to completely replace the section containing the controls and chart with a clearer, stacked layout: grouped range and view selectors, refreshed metric select with helper text, category filters shown conditionally, and a unified chart area below with dynamic titles and info labels based on current view and selections. I'll compute derived labels via useMemo and keep the interface consistent and accessible. The update involves a large JSX patch replacing the controls block up to the loading overlay, carefully restructuring all these pieces together.

payload.text:
**Analyzing module resolution issues in monorepo**

I'm piecing together why the dev server can't find `react-day-picker` in a monorepo using npm workspaces. The user might be running commands either in the root or apps/web folder, causing inconsistent node_modules presence. The bundler fails because the imported component is new and requires `react-day-picker`, which may not be installed or hoisted properly at the root. I'll need to verify workspace installs and hoisting to resolve this.

**Evaluating dependency resolution strategies**

I'm weighing options to fix bundler issues with react-day-picker, including vendoring the module by copying its build files, adjusting import paths, lazy loading to avoid static analysis, or linking node_modules to ensure resolution from the root. I'll aim for a solution that avoids build errors and fits the user's environment best.

**Considering fallback for missing DayPicker dependency**

I'm thinking about how to handle the missing or problematic DayPicker dependency causing errors. One option is creating a minimal stub of DayPicker to satisfy imports by mimicking only the needed subset for date range selection with simple native inputs—this could keep the existing Calendar component roughly functional. Alternatively, I could adjust the LineHistoryDashboard to use a basic inline date range picker with two input fields, avoiding DayPicker entirely but possibly changing the UI from what the user expects. summary.text:
**Analyzing module resolution issues in monorepo**

I'm piecing together why the dev server can't find `react-day-picker` in a monorepo using npm workspaces. The user might be running commands either in the root or apps/web folder, causing inconsistent node_modules presence. The bundler fails because the imported component is new and requires `react-day-picker`, which may not be installed or hoisted properly at the root. I'll need to verify workspace installs and hoisting to resolve this.

**Evaluating dependency resolution strategies**

I'm weighing options to fix bundler issues with react-day-picker, including vendoring the module by copying its build files, adjusting import paths, lazy loading to avoid static analysis, or linking node_modules to ensure resolution from the root. I'll aim for a solution that avoids build errors and fits the user's environment best.

**Considering fallback for missing DayPicker dependency**

I'm thinking about how to handle the missing or problematic DayPicker dependency causing errors. One option is creating a minimal stub of DayPicker to satisfy imports by mimicking only the needed subset for date range selection with simple native inputs—this could keep the existing Calendar component roughly functional. Alternatively, I could adjust the LineHistoryDashboard to use a basic inline date range picker with two input fields, avoiding DayPicker entirely but possibly changing the UI from what the user expects. The user seems to prefer keeping the Calendar as-is, so I’m weighing the trade-offs between quick fixes via stubbing or refactoring usage.

**Redesigning chart filters and views**

I'm reworking the chart to remove the view dropdown entirely and rely solely on multi-select dropdown filters per dimension. The chart will consistently show date vs. count, aggregating totals filtered by selected categories across all dimensions. I'll merge series data for these filters, default to totals if none selected, and simplify state by removing view logic while preserving metrics controls. This will ensure the chart shape stays consistent while supporting multi-dimensional filtering.

payload.text:
**Redesigning multi-dimension filter handling and chart rendering**

I'm planning to remove the view selection UI and update filtering to support combined series across multiple selected dimensions. I’ll implement a mergeSeries helper to unify series data by date, adjust chart rendering to always show a line chart with date on the x-axis and counts on the y-axis, display totals if no filters are applied, and clean up related state and UI elements accordingly. I want to keep metrics selection and ensure the UI reflects per-dimension dropdown filters and updated summary text.

summary.text:
**Redesigning multi-dimension filter handling and chart rendering**

I'm planning to remove the view selection UI and update filtering to support combined series across multiple selected dimensions. I’ll implement a mergeSeries helper to unify series data by date, adjust chart rendering to always show a line chart with date on the x-axis and counts on the y-axis, display totals if no filters are applied, and clean up related state and UI elements accordingly. I want to keep metrics selection and ensure the UI reflects per-dimension dropdown filters and updated summary text.

- Removed the old 단일 “보기 선택” flow; now all quick-view dimensions (SDWT Prod, Process, Step, PPID, SDWT, User SDWT) are individual dropdowns with multi-select checkboxes. Selections persist per dimension and can be reset.
- Date range dropdown remains, using the inline date range picker; query params include from/to and rangeDays.
- Chart logic simplified: always date on X and counts on Y. If any filters are selected and data exists, merged series across all chosen dimensions render together; otherwise, the totals-by-date series shows. Metrics remain multi-select checkboxes, and the legend reflects the active metric lines.
- Helper utilities added (`mergeSeries`, reuse `buildTotals`) to merge multiple dimension series into one dataset.

content.text:
- Removed the old 단일 “보기 선택” flow; now all quick-view dimensions (SDWT Prod, Process, Step, PPID, SDWT, User SDWT) are individual dropdowns with multi-select checkboxes. Selections persist per dimension and can be reset.
- Date range dropdown remains, using the inline date range picker; query params include from/to and rangeDays.
- Chart logic simplified: always date on X and counts on Y. If any filters are selected and data exists, merged series across all chosen dimensions render together; otherwise, the totals-by-date series shows. Metrics remain multi-select checkboxes, and the legend reflects the active metric lines.
- Helper utilities added (`mergeSeries`, reuse `buildTotals`) to merge multiple dimension series into one dataset.

payload.message:
- Fixed filter plumbing so selections stick and render correctly:
  - Initialize `selectedFilters` with all dimensions up front instead of empty.
  - Preserve selections when dimension totals update (no more resets), and normalize Radix checkbox values (`checked === true`) to avoid toggling bugs.
  - Prefixed series keys with the dimension to avoid collisions and ensure filtered lines show up per dropdown selection.
- Chart now merges filtered series with dimension-aware labels/colors; if no filter data, it falls back to the date totals view.

content.text:
- Fixed filter plumbing so selections stick and render correctly:
  - Initialize `selectedFilters` with all dimensions up front instead of empty.
  - Preserve selections when dimension totals update (no more resets), and normalize Radix checkbox values (`checked === true`) to avoid toggling bugs.
  - Prefixed series keys with the dimension to avoid collisions and ensure filtered lines show up per dropdown selection.
- Chart now merges filtered series with dimension-aware labels/colors; if no filter data, it falls back to the date totals view.

File touched: `apps/web/src/features/line-dashboard/history/LineHistoryDashboard.jsx`.
